courseDescription: An introductory course in robotics dealing with the history and development of robots, mechanical components and control systems, actuators, robot programming and utilization. Included are laboratory experiments in robot motion and programming.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of robot history and development
Knowledge of mechanical components and control systems

courseDescription: Principles of design for manufacturing, materials and process selection for design, design for assembly, design for production and case studies. Also includes impact of product design, design for maintenance, recyclability, disassembly, quality and robustness. Semester project requires redesign of an existing product for manufacturing.
Technical and Digital Skills: Materials and process selection for design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative redesign of an existing product
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Selection of appropriate materials and processes

courseDescription: A study of the mechatronics concepts and their application on actual problems encountered in engineering practice. Includes the basics of electromechanical systems, electrical circuits, solid-state devices, digital circuits and motors, all of which are fundamental to understanding mechatronic systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of mechatronics concepts in engineering practice
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying mechatronics concepts to solve real-world engineering problems
Analyzing and interpreting complex electromechanical systems

courseDescription: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of quality systems within the realm of manufacturing. Students will delve into the principles, methodologies, and tools essential for ensuring and enhancing product quality throughout the manufacturing lifecycle. Topics covered include quality management systems, statistical process control, Six Sigma methodologies, root cause analysis, quality assurance practices, and the integration of quality systems within various manufacturing processes. Through case studies and practical applications, students will gain a deep understanding of how quality systems contribute to operational excellence and competitive advantage in modern manufacturing environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of quality systems within manufacturing processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of quality system findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for statistical process control
Application of Six Sigma methodologies for problem solving
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of quality systems within manufacturing processes
Leadership in implementing quality assurance practices

courseDescription: This course offers an in-depth examination of material handling technologies, automatic identification, and data capture techniques. Students will grasp the concepts underlying manufacturing support systems, delve into the realm of digital manufacturing, and gain proficiency in manufacturing process simulation. Through practical applications and theoretical frameworks, this course equips learners with a comprehensive understanding of how technology intersects with modern manufacturing processes.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of technology's role in modern manufacturing processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and optimization of manufacturing processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and implementing manufacturing support systems
Organizing and controlling automated manufacturing processes

courseDescription: Methods and rules of dimensioning and tolerancing, calculation of fits, and geometrical tolerances using ANSI-Y14.5M, tolerances of form, orientation, and profile, including flatness, straightness, circularity, cylindricity, angularity, etc. Student work consists of designing and detailing various product drawings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to design and detail product drawings
Knowledge of tolerances of form, orientation, and profile
Understanding of flatness, straightness, circularity, cylindricity, angularity
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to convey design details and specifications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in dimensional and tolerancing issues
Analytical skills in calculating fits and tolerances

courseDescription: Principles of computer numerical control consistent with most recently developed standards, industry practices, and CAD/CAM systems including such topics as types of CNC machines, CNC milling, CNC turning and CNC electro-discharge machinery. A significant portion of the course includes programming in multiple axes.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to adhere to industry practices

courseDescription: An introduction to conventional and non-conventional welding processes. This course is intended to provide the student with a basic understanding of the various welding processes, welding terminology, joints, symbols, welding defects, equipment. Topics covered include welding processes, heat and fluid flow, structure of metals, solidification phenomena, phase transformations, residual stresses, and nondestructive examination techniques. Real life examples will be used to illustrate the fundamental concepts of the course. The student will also be introduced to career opportunities in the welding field. Lab time will be used to enforce lecture topics when needed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of conventional and non-conventional welding processes
Familiarity with welding terminology, joints, symbols, welding defects
Knowledge of heat and fluid flow, structure of metals, solidification phenomena, phase transformations, residual stresses
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain fundamental welding concepts using real life examples
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of heat and fluid flow

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of various additive manufacturing (AM) processes. Topics include fundamentals of polymer, composite, and metal AM processes, process parameters, AM software, AM cost, and AM’s industrial potential such as prototyping, tooling, production customization, spare parts, art, design, architecture and construction.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on fundamentals of polymer, composite, and metal AM processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the industrial potential of AM
Customizing production according to AM capabilities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing AM projects from prototyping to production
Planning for spare parts using AM
Leading design initiatives in art, architecture, and construction using AM

courseDescription: This course explores the intricate methods and technologies revolutionizing manufacturing, encompassing additive manufacturing, precision machining, sustainable and green processes and technologies, custom manufacturing, intelligent production systems, digital manufacturing, and digital twin. Through case studies and practical applications, learners develop a comprehensive understanding of innovative manufacturing processes driving efficiency, precision, and competitiveness in industry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of sustainable and green processes and technologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating efficiency, precision, and competitiveness in industry

courseDescription: This course looks at the history of lean and six sigma philosophies, their principles and implementation methodologies for creating a world class enterprise. Topics in Lean include 5s, value stream mapping, cellular manufacturing, pull system, performance metrics, Lean supplier network, Lean product development and Lean implementation models. Through theory and practical applications, students gain a foundational grasp of Lean Manufacturing and its real-world applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Lean and Six Sigma philosophies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for a world-class enterprise

courseDescription: This course takes a systematic approach to design of facilities and material handling systems for effective and lean production of goods and services. An array of qualitative and quantitative tools and techniques are introduced and utilized, emphasizing lean principles, waste reduction, and overall efficiency of operations. Flow analysis and optimization tools, including computer simulation, are introduced. Strong emphasis is placed on a comprehensive semester-long team project as an integral component of this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Systematic design of facilities and material handling systems
Use of qualitative and quantitative tools and techniques
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Effective problem solving using lean principles
